title: RS22607
content: It is a federal crime to assault, kidnap, or kill a federal judge or their family members with the intent to obstruct or retaliate for the judge's duties. The law also protects federal law enforcement officers, prosecutors, and any federal officer or employee. Penalties are based on the seriousness of the offense. Section 207 of P.L. 110-177 increases the maximum penalties. The penalties for obstructing federal duties, including assault, kidnapping, or killing federal judges, officers, and employees, have been increased under Section 207 of P.L. 110-177. This amendment extends to manslaughter committed under various federal jurisdictional circumstances, providing protection for witnesses in federal judicial, Congressional, and administrative proceedings. The federal obstruction of justice statutes outlaw murder, assaults, and threats to influence witness testimony or retaliate for past testimony. Penalties for crimes against federal witnesses are the same as for crimes against federal officials, with increased penalties for assault and conspiracy. Sections 205 and 206 of P.L. 110-177 increase maximum penalties for witness tampering or retaliation involving physical force. Section 204 adds a venue provision to witness retaliation offenses. Section 204 of P.L. 110-177 increases penalties for witness tampering or retaliation, with venue provisions allowing prosecution in either the place of violation or where the proceeding occurred. The Constitution may limit the reach of this section, as prosecution outside where the offense occurred raises constitutional concerns. In addition to violence against federal officials and witnesses, federal laws also prohibit the misuse of firearms and explosives. For example, 18 U.S.C. 930 prohibits the use of firearms. Federal criminal prohibitions address the use of violence against federal officials, witnesses, and proceedings, including the misuse of firearms and dangerous weapons. For instance, 18 U.S.C. 930 prohibits the use of firearms or dangerous weapons in federal facilities, with penalties for possession or attempted possession within these facilities. The federal criminal prohibitions include penalties for possession of firearms or dangerous weapons within federal facilities or courthouses. The definition of "dangerous weapon" is broad and includes items that could be misused to inflict serious injury. The definition of "dangerous weapon" includes innocent objects that could be misused to cause harm, posing practical problems when it comes to possession in federal courthouses. Retaliation against federal officials has involved filing false liens and legal nuisance actions, prosecuted under federal statutes prohibiting obstruction of justice or conspiracy to retaliate. Filing false liens and legal nuisance actions against federal officials is a form of retaliation that can result in federal prosecution. Specific federal statutes prohibit such actions, including threats or harm towards federal officers, employees, or their families in relation to their duties. Additionally, knowingly filing false liens against federal officers' property is a separate federal crime punishable by up to 10 years in prison. Threatening witnesses in federal proceedings is also considered a federal offense. It is a federal offense to threaten or harm federal officers, employees, or their families to impede their duties. Threatening witnesses in federal proceedings is also a federal crime. Additionally, making certain identifying information of federal officials publicly available is prohibited by federal law. Section 202 of P.L. 110-177 criminalizes the public disclosure of certain identifying information about federal officials, employees, witnesses, and jurors with the intent to threaten or incite violence. Offenders can face up to 5 years in prison, regardless of the victims' federal or family status. First Amendment concerns may limit the scope of this law. The United States Marshals Service, under the Department of Justice, is responsible for security in federal courts, executing warrants, protecting witnesses, and arresting fugitives. Marshals are appointed by the President and serve four-year terms. Section 103 calls for an additional $20 million in funding. The United States Marshals Service is responsible for security in federal courts, executing warrants, protecting witnesses, and arresting fugitives. Section 103 calls for an additional $20 million in funding for hiring additional marshals to provide security for federal judges and assistant United States attorneys. The Marshals Service receives $25.7 million for investigating threats against the Judiciary, trial security, and enforcement of the Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act. P.L. 110-177 amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide security for the Tax Court and its participants. The Judicial Conference oversees federal court operations. Section 101 of P.L. 110-177 amends statutes for the Marshals Service and the Judicial Conference to ensure consultation on judicial security and threat assessment. Federal judges and prosecutors face threats, with marshals having authority to carry firearms. Prosecutors can be deputized as deputy marshals for this authority. Section 401 of P.L. 110-177 directs the Attorney General to report on the security of federal prosecutors, including firearm possession matters. Part H of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 authorizes grants for state prosecutors, with appropriations authorized until FY2000. Section 301 of P.L. 110-177 amends Part H to include state witness protection programs and authorizes appropriations of $20 million annually through 2011. Sections 515 and 516 of the Omnibus Crime and Safe Streets Act of 1968 authorize discretionary grants for the Bureau of Justice Assistance. P.L. 110-177 amends Part H to include state witness protection programs and authorizes $20 million annually through 2011. Sections 515 and 516 of the Omnibus Crime and Safe Streets Act of 1968 authorize grants for the Bureau of Justice Assistance. Section 302 allows 10% of funds for grants to improve security for court systems, with a priority for those in greatest need. The new allotment prioritizes those with the greatest need, reducing appropriations for corrections alternatives from 80% to 70%. Section 302 also includes matching grants for armored vests for state and territorial court officers. The Attorney General can require applicants to consider security needs after consulting with judicial and law enforcement authorities. The United States Sentencing Commission establishes sentencing guidelines for federal courts in criminal cases. The United States Sentencing Commission, established in 1984, provides sentencing guidelines for federal courts in criminal cases. While these guidelines were once binding, they are now advisory but still carry persuasive force. The Commission can enter into contracts to fulfill its responsibilities, with some exceptions allowing for multi-year contracts and advance payments under certain conditions. The heads of executive agencies and the judicial branch have exceptions to the general rule regarding contracting for services. Section 501 of P.L. 110-177 grants the Sentencing Commission authority, while Section 502 eases life insurance costs for magistrate judges. Senior judges can be designated to perform judicial duties within the circuit. Judicial councils can assign senior judges to perform judicial duties within the circuit, granting them all powers except for appointing statutory positions. Various positions in the judicial branch have specific appointment authorities, such as bankruptcy judges appointed by the Circuit Court of Appeals. Regular active service judges have certain powers that senior judges do not possess. Court judges appoint their clerks and court reporters; individual judges appoint bailiffs, law clerks, and secretaries. Only judges in "regular active service" can make certain decisions, such as presenting an appeal to all judges of a circuit. Senior judges can participate in en banc appeals only if they were part of the original panel. They can also serve on the Judicial Conference and judicial councils for their circuits. Section 503 of P.L. 110-177 amends 28 U.S.C. 296 to grant certain senior judges full powers of a judge in their appointed court, including participation in appointment of court officers, rulemaking, and administrative matters. This amendment overrides limitations on en banc and appointment participation. Magistrate judges are appointed by district court judges. The amendment in Section 504 of P.L. 110-177 expands the appointment authority of United States magistrate judges to include retired district court judges, presenting an interpretative challenge due to retirement differences among judges in various regions. The amendment in Section 504 of P.L. 110-177 expands the appointment authority of United States magistrate judges to include retired district court judges, specifically those under Section 371(b). Additionally, P.L. 110-177 includes provisions such as increasing judgeships on the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals and directing studies on the impact of state and local open access laws on federal judicial security. The District of Columbia Circuit Court of Appeals is reduced from 12 to 11 judges. Section 506 of P.L. 110-177 requires the Attorney General to study the impact of state and local open access laws on federal judicial security. Section 510 mandates a study by the National Institute of Justice on the consequences of conviction under federal and state law.
